bestBHT.bht: The phrase he that seeth me points to the abiding result of Christ's manifestation and signifies his divine essence. By contemplating Christ, we gain a deeper knowledge of the Father. Our faith in Christ is firmly established on the eternal God, not reliant on human understanding. It should be unwavering and boldly expressed, shining God's glory in the world. Through faith in Christ, we not only see Him but also behold the One who sent Him.

Albert Barnes: In no other way can it be true that he who saw Jesus saw him that sent him, unless he were the same in essence.
Of no man could it be affirmed that he who saw him saw God.
It shows that he had a consciousness that he was divine, and that it was the natural and proper way of speaking when speaking of himself.
Marvin Vincent: The word is purposely chosen to mark an intent, continuous contemplation of Christ, issuing in ever larger knowledge of the Father.
The perfect tense, pointing to the abiding result of His manifestation.
John Calvin: The reason why the stability of faith is firm and secure is, that it is stronger than the world, and is above the world.
Now, when Christ is truly known, the glory of God shines in him, that we may be fully persuaded that the faith which we have in him does not depend on man, but that it is founded on the eternal God.
And, if it be so, not only must it be fixed perpetually in our hearts, but it must likewise show itself boldly in the tongue, when it is necessary.
Philip Schaff: And he that beholdeth me, beholdeth him that sent me."
He that beholdeth the Son and believeth in Him."
He that beholdeth me, beholdeth him that sent me.
John Gill: Not with bodily eyes, for there were many that saw Christ, who never saw the Father.
Whoever saw the glory of Christ in his miracles, saw the glory of God in them also.
He that hath seen the one, hath seen the other also.
John Wesley: And he that seeth me — By the eye of faith.

bhtAttempts.bht: By continuously contemplating Christ, we can gain a deeper understanding of the Father. The phrase he that seeth me points to the abiding result of Christ's manifestation. This unique phrase highlights the divine essence of Jesus and his consciousness of being divine. When we behold the Son and believe in Him, we also behold the One who sent Him. Our faith in Christ is not dependent on human understanding, but rather on the eternal God. Therefore, our faith should be unwavering and boldly expressed, for it is stronger than the world and shines the glory of God.

It should be unwavering, confidently expressed, and shine the glory of God above the world. Through faith in Christ, we not only see Him but also behold the One who sent Him.
